posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I have visited the concept of a full-plate warrior that emerges from the shadows and delivers incredible punishment twice in the past, in the form of The Dark Assailant and The Shadow Warrior, both weapon masters in the trade. I always took measures to correct their inherent weaknesses, namely their faulty saving throws above all else. The solution that I found comes from abolishing the weapon master part and welcoming the true and trusty Champion of Torm, as it not only corrects that part but leaves enough bonus feats to have everything I've ever wanted and then some. Here comes Knight Artorias with 50 stealth in full-plate armour, delivering improved knockdown-devastating critical alpha-strikes with maximum strength and then melding into the shadows again, rinse and repeat.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I don't know, he clears off for months on end, then pops back in and delivers a splendid build like this. It's all very annoying and not at all surprising!

I don't have anything really to add...except that Artorias would obviously make a splendid dwarf (easy enough to lose LoH), except the loss of skill points could really hurt. Oh well.

I did make use of the 3 classes myself (F12/ CoT 14/ SD 14), but as a dual-wielding Epic Dodger, in my Lostara Yil build. She's an RP build, though, so not min-maxed. It's nice to see the potential flexibility of the 3 classes though.

A great build, Valerfor - thanks!

EDIT: Been thinking a bit more about a dwarven version - and you don't need to lose those skill points. Keep CON at 12 and make both INT and DEX 14 - ta-da! So, you'd just lose 1 to all saves (except Reflex) - meh. Short beardies for the win!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
A fine build, Valerfor!
Dev crit from the shadows should give most enemies nightmares.
AB 45 is a very good warrior AB. For dropping dev crit attacks against the flat-footed and unsuspecting, it is almost overkill (pun not intended).
This one should work well as a front line fighter too, even if it has less than 500 hp. You can bolster your defences with Shadow evade, or bail out with HIPS if it gets too rough.
The saves are very good and have a good synergy with several of the defensive feats from the SD class.
Even with 14 fighter- and 10 CoT levels, you have to make priorities, and I can understand why you chose to drop EWS.
I only have one minor suggestion, and that is to start taking listen one level earlier. You have 7 skill points to play with at lvl 26.

Stag has shown how you can build this one as a dwarf. Actually, you can do the same with Half-orc (!) starting with Str 18, dex 14, con 12, wis 8, Int 14, cha 6. But also there, you have to drop one of the less essential pre-epic feats to make it work.

Been looking for something like this for quite a long time.  Thank you.  Thinking about dropping and early feat for exotic to use a Falcion for the better Crit range and gving it a go!
Luck of Heroes would be my choice to drop for Exotic Weapons (which would also make shield and katana or bastard sword possible, but you'd lose the 1.5 damage).

A potential tweak, while I'm thinking about it, would be to lose 2 Great Strengths and take EWS as a Fighter general feat, then take Epic Fortitude to better oppose Dev Crits coming your way. I'm not saying you should, only that you could.

Cheers

posts.author: BarrettCole
posts.content: That build is an absolute powerhouse—melding stealth, heavy armor, and devastating critical strikes into a near-unstoppable force. posts.author: InfiniteChill
posts.content:
This is SUCH a cool build. I ran through the first act and Interlude of Shadows of Undrentide with it over the weekend and it was highly playable for the first several levels, with standard Fighter weaknesses that fade as CoT levels come into play. You can't really hide with heavy armor on until level 9, as you'd expect. 

I know this isn't really the place for it; but, I'm going to try to adapt this build for NWN2. It just feel so thematically close to the OC and MotB.
